facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1952, of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: Appeal from Calcutta High Court judgment dated March 21, 1952 in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 971 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1952, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 971 of 1950, arising out of the judgment and decree dated August 29, 1950,

facts.text: District Judge of Zillah Burdwan judgment dated August 29, 1950 in Title Appeal No. 247/16 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated August 29, 1950, of the Court of District Judge of Zillah Burdwan in Title Appeal No. 247/16 of 1948 against judgment and decree dated September 25, 1948,

facts.text: Additional Sub-Judge, 1st Court, Burdwan judgment dated September 25, 1948 in Title Suit No. 7 of 1946/27 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: of the Court of Additional Sub-Judge, 1st Court, Burdwan, in Title Suit No. 7 of 1946/27 of 1947. 1311 C. Chatterjee and Sukumar Ghose, for the appellant. N. Banerjee and P. K. Ghose, for the respondents. 1958. September 18.

facts.text: Suit property is a Mahal of 84 Bighas 18 Cottas in lot Ahiyapur village, part of Burdwan Zamindari.

anchor.surface_text: The suit property is a Mahal of the extent of 84 Bighas 18 Cottas situated within lot Ahiyapur village, which is one of the villages forming part of the permanently settled estate of Burdwan Zamindari.

facts.text: Village granted by Maharaja of Burdwan in Patni to predecessors-in-title of defendants 1 to 7 prior to Bengal Regulation VIII of 1819.

anchor.surface_text: This village was granted by the Maharaja of Burdwan in Patni settlement to the predecessors- in-title of defendants I to 7. The exact date of this grant does number appear, but it is stated that it was sometime prior to the enactment of the Bengal Patni Taluks Regulation, 1819

facts.text: Mahal set apart as Chaukidari Chakaran lands prior to permanent settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The Mahal with which this litigation is companycerned, had been at or prior to the permanent settlement set apart as Chaukidari Chakaran lands that is to say, they were to be held by the Chaukidars for rendering service in the village as watchmen.

facts.text: Village Chaukidari Act, 1870 (Ben. VI of 1870) passed.

anchor.surface_text: In 1870, the Village Chaukidari Act, 1870  Ben. VI of 1870 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, was passed, and s. 48 of that Act provides that all Chaukidari Chakaran lands assigned for the benefit of any village shall be transferred to the zamindar

facts.text: Suit properties transferred to Maharaja of Burdwan under Village Chaukidari Act.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the provisions aforesaid, the suit properties were transferred to the Maharaja of Burdwan, and on June 3,1899, he granted the same to the predecessors-in- title of defendants I to 7, who at that time held the Patni interest

facts.text: Maharaja granted suit lands on June 3, 1899 to predecessors of defendants 1-7 (Exhibit B), yearly rental Rs. 126-8 as.

anchor.surface_text: and on June 3,1899, he granted the same to the predecessors-in- title of defendants I to 7, who at that time held the Patni interest in respect of lot Ahiyapur. Under the grant which has been marked as exhibit B, the yearly rental for the area was fixed at Rs. 126-8 as.,

facts.text: Maharaja auctioned suit lands on May 15, 1937 under Regulation VIII of 1819 for arrears, purchased himself.

anchor.surface_text: Acting under this clause, the Maharaja applied under s. 8 of the Regulation to bring the suit lands to sale for realisation of arrears, and at the auction held on May 15, 1937, himself became the purchaser.

facts.text: Maharaja granted lands on February 13, 1941 to appellant as Patni.

anchor.surface_text: On February 13, 1941, he granted the lands again on Patni to the appellant, who filed the suit, out of which the present appeal arises, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Burdwan,

facts.text: Appellant filed ejectment suit alleging trespass by defendants.

anchor.surface_text: to recover possession thereof from the defendants alleging that they had trespassed thereon. The respondents companytested the suit on the ground that, in fact, there were numberarrears of rent due under Exhibit B, and that the sale was therefore void.

facts.text: Respondents claimed no arrears of rent under Exhibit B, sale void.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytested the suit on the ground that, in fact, there were numberarrears of rent due under Exhibit B, and that the sale was therefore void.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held arrears due, no suit under s.14 Reg, decreed suit for plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that there were arrears of rent due from the respondents, and that further as they had number sued to set aside the sale under s. 14 of the Regulation within the time limited by law, they companyld number set up its invalidity

facts.text: District Judge dismissed defendants' appeal, held Exhibit B created new Patni, sale valid.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants preferred an appeal against this judgment to the District Court of Burdwan, and there raised a new companytention that under the grant, Exhibit B, the suit lands became part of lot Ahiyapur, and that a sale of those lands was 1313 illegal

facts.text: Calcutta High Court (Das Gupta and Lahiri JJ) allowed second appeal, held lands part of Patni, sale void, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents took the matter in second appeal to the High Court, and that was heard by a Bench companysisting of Das Gupta and Lahiri JJ. who differed from the District Judge both on the companystruction of Exhibit B and on the bar of limitation

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment that the present appeal has been brought on a certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  a .

facts.text: Defendants did not raise plea in trial court that lands part of lot Ahiyapur Patni.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant urged the following companytentions in support of the appeal  1  The defendants did number raise either in the written statement or during the trial, the plea that under the sanad, Exhibit B,

facts.text: Supreme Court held Exhibit B created a new distinct Patni, sale valid.

anchor.surface_text: Construing Exhibit B, as a whole, we are of opinion that the intention of the parties as expressed therein was that the Chaukidari Chakaran lands should be held as a distinct Patni.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected High Court view, held earlier clause prevails.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Exhibit B created a new Patni and that the sale of the lands companyprised therein is number bad as of a portion of a, Patni.

issues.text: Whether the defendants raised the plea that under Exhibit B the Chaukidari Chakaran lands became part of lot Ahiyapur Patni making the sale bad as a sale of part Patni in the trial court such that the High Court should not have allowed it in appeal?

anchor.surface_text: 1 The defendants did number raise either in the written statement or during the trial, the plea that under the sanad, Exhibit B, the Chaukidari Chakaran lands comprised therein became part of the Patni settlement of lot Ahiyapur, and, in consequence, their sale was bad as being of a part of the Patni,

issues.text: Whether Exhibit B properly construed creates a new Patni distinct from lot Ahiyapur such that its sale is valid?

anchor.surface_text: 2 Exhibit B properly companystrued must be held to create a new Patni distinct from lot Ahiyapur, and its sale is therefore valid.

issues.text: Assuming the sale invalid as of part of tenure, whether defendants could attack it collaterally or were barred by not suing under s.14 of the Regulation?

anchor.surface_text: 3 Assuming that the sale is invalid as being of a part of a tenure, the only right of the defendants was to sue to have it set aside, as provided in s. 14 of the Regulation, and that number having been done, it is number open to them to attack it companylaterally in these proceedings.

issues.text: The true character of the grant under Exhibit B: whether it amounts to a new Patni distinct from lot Ahiyapur or incorporates the lands into the Patni of lot Ahiyapur making them part thereof?

anchor.surface_text: The next point for determination is as to the true character of the grant under Exhibit B, whether it amounts to a new Patni with reference to the Chaukidari Chakaran lands as contended for by the appellant, or whether it incorporates those lands in the Patni of lot Ahiyapur, so as to make them part and parcel of the lands comprised therein,

holdings.text: The first contention has no substance; the point regarding the construction of Exhibit B could be raised in appeal as it is a pure question of law based on the terms of the document requiring no evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We see nosubstance in the first contention. It is 1314 true that the defendants did number put forward in the trial Court the plea that the effect of Exhibit B was to incorporate the suit lands in lot Ahiyapur Patni, and that, in consequence, the sale was illegal as being of a part of the Patni. On the other hand, the written statement proceeds on the view that Exhibit B created a new Patni unconnected with lot Ahiyapur, and the only defence raised on that basis was that noarrears of rent were due under Exhibit B, and that the sale was therefore invalid. But the true nature of the grant under Exhibit B is a matter to be decided on a construction of the terms of the document, and that is a question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of grant is pure question of law; no extrinsic evidence admissible upon undisputed document terms; cites Balkishen Das v. Legge and Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La; no objection raised in District Court.

holdings.text: Construing Exhibit B as a whole, the intention of the parties was that the Chaukidari Chakaran lands should be held as a distinct Patni.

anchor.surface_text: Construing Exhibit B, as a whole, we are of opinion that the intention of the parties as expressed therein was that the Chaukidari Chakaran lands should be held as a distinct Patni. We must number refer to the decision on which the learned Judges in the Court below have relied in support of their conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document read wholly; recital of new settlement; sale clause valid only if separate Patni; harmonious construction preferring effect to all clauses; later clauses reconciled as indemnity and cesser provisions; transfer/succession clauses support distinctness.

holdings.text: Exhibit B created a new Patni and the sale of the lands comprised therein is not bad as of a portion of a Patni.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Exhibit B created a new Patni and that the sale of the lands comprised therein is number bad as of a portion of a, Patni. We are conscious that we are differing from the learned Judges of the Court below on a question relating to a local tenure on which their opinion is, by reason of the special knowledge and experience which they have of it, entitled to the greatest weight.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies construction rules to facts of grant; distinguishes Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra as not considering sale clause; reverses High Court.

holdings.text: In case of irreconcilable conflict between clauses in a deed, the earlier clause prevails over the later repugnant clause.

anchor.surface_text: If, in fact, there is a conflict between the earlier clause and the later clauses and it is number possible to give effect to all of them, then the rule of construction is well-established that it is the earlier clause that must override the later clauses and number vice versa. In Forbes v. Git Lord Wrenbury stated the rule in the following terms

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-established rule applied to reconcile clauses in Exhibit B; cites Forbes v. Git; earlier sale provision overrides later if conflict.

holdings.text: If two constructions of a document are possible, prefer the one giving effect to all clauses over one rendering some nugatory (ut res magis valeat quam pereat).

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is a settled rule of interpretation that if there be admissible two constructions of a document, one of which will give effect to all the clauses therein while the other will render one or more of them nugatory, it is the former that should be adopted on the principle expressed in the maxim ut res magis valeat quam per-eat . What has to be considered therefore is whether it is possible to give effect to the clause in question,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to construe Exhibit B to validate sale clause by treating as distinct Patni; avoids nugatory effect.

precedents.cited_proposition: no evidence is admissible on a question of construction of a contract or grant, which must be based solely on the terms of the document

precedents.citation: Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La 2

anchor.surface_text: Vide Balkishen Das v. Legge  1  and Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La  2 . It should, moreover, be mentioned that when the defendants sought to raise this contention in their appeal in the District Court, no objection was taken by the plaintiff thereto. Under the circumstances, the learned Judges were right in allowing this point to be taken.

precedents.case_name: Maung Kyin v. Ma Shwe La
precedents.cited_proposition: no evidence is admissible on a question of construction of a contract or grant, which must be based solely on the terms of the document

precedents.citation: Ranjit Singh v. Maharaj Bahadur Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ranjit Singh v. Maharaj Bahadur Singh  1 , it was held by the Privy Council that though the reservation under s. 51 is of rights under contracts made by the Zamindar and the word contract primarily means a transaction which creates personal obligations, it might also refer to transactions which create real rights, and that it was in that sense the word was used in s. 51, and that accordingly the Patnidar was entitled to institute a suit against the Zamindar for possession of those lands and was not obliged to suit for specific performance.

precedents.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. Maharaj Bahadur Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: reservation under s. 51 includes real rights of Patnidar to Chaukidari lands allowing suit for possession
precedents.cited_holding: Patnidar entitled to possession without specific performance

precedents.citation: Bhupendra Narayan Singh v. Narapat Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: Vide Bhupendra Narayan Singh v. Narapat Singh  1 , where it was held by the Privy Council that when Chaukidari Chakaran lands included in a Patni settlement had been resumed and transferred to the Zamindar under s. 51 of the Act, he is entitled to the payment of a fair and equitable rent in respect thereof, and that the fixing of the rent is a condition to the Patnidar being put in possession.

precedents.case_name: Bhupendra Narayan Singh v. Narapat Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Zamindar entitled to fair rent from Patnidar for Chaukidari lands under s. 51
precedents.cited_holding: fixing of rent condition to possession

precedents.citation: Rajendra Nath Mukherjee v. Hiralal Mukherjee 2

anchor.surface_text: Vide also Rajendra Nath Mukherjee v. Hiralal Mukherjee  2  and Gopendra Chandra v. Taraprasanna  3 . anchor.surface_text: We must number refer to the decision on which the learned Judges in the Court below have relied in support of their conclusion. In Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra  1 , the facts were that the Maharaja of Burdwan had created a Patni of lot Kooly in 1820.

precedents.case_name: Kanchan Barani Debi v. Umesh Chandra
precedents.cited_proposition: Chaukidari lands granted post-resumption merged into original Patni
precedents.cited_holding: purchaser of original Patni entitled to Chaukidari lands

anchor.surface_text: In Forbes v. Git  1 , Lord Wrenbury stated the rule in the following terms If in a deed an earlier clause is followed by a later clause which destroys altogether the obligation created by the earlier clause, the later clause is to be rejected as repugnant and the earlier clause prevails.

precedents.cited_proposition: earlier clause prevails over later repugnant clause in deed
precedents.cited_holding: later clause rejected if destroys earlier obligation

anchor.surface_text: We see nosubstance in the first contention. It is 1314 true that the defendants did number put forward in the trial Court the plea that the effect of Exhibit B was to incorporate the suit lands in lot Ahiyapur Patni, and that, in consequence, the sale was illegal as being of a part of the Patni. On the other hand, the written statement proceeds on the view that Exhibit B created a new Patni unconnected with lot Ahiyapur, and the only defence raised on that basis was that noarrears of rent were due under Exhibit B, and that the sale was therefore invalid. But the true nature of the grant under Exhibit B is a matter to be decided on a construction of the terms of the document, and that is a question of law.
We accordingly hold that Exhibit B created a new Patni and that the sale of the lands comprised therein is not bad as of a portion of a Patni.
pose of this clause is, in our opinion, number so much to declare the rights of those other persons which rest on statutory recognition, but to provid

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that Exhibit B created a new Patni and that the sale of the lands comprised therein is number bad as of a portion of a, Patni. We are conscious that we are differing from the learned Judges of the Court below on a question relating to a local tenure on which their opinion is, by reason of the special knowledge and experience which they have of it, entitled to the greatest weight.
We accordingly hold that Exhibit B created a new Patni and that the sale of the lands comprised therein is not bad as of a portion of a Patni.
